Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: [Admin UI] Allow admins to select a specific number of package versions in the Admin Unlist UI" (#9517) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

When we have to unlist many package versions at once, we often need to break it up into smaller batches. We could add the ability to select the first 'X' <unlisted/listed> package versions to help with this.

We could also show how many package versions have been selected (possibly in the button text). Right now, we show it as an alert that pops up once we've clicked the button, but showing it earlier would be more useful.

### Repro Steps

1. Go to the Bulk Unlist UI in the Admin Panel
2. Enter names of packages you need to unlist
3. Scroll down

### Expected Behavior

1. Add the ability to select the first 'X' <unlisted/listed> package versions among those shown.

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/82980589/e18a7e6a-2edf-4096-bcb0-2bd1f2139dd9)

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/82980589/2aacb376-6d0d-44c0-bc21-c5d442bcf831)

2. Show how many package versions have been selected (possibly in the button text)

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Changing selected Version briefly flickers to the README tab" (#9985) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

When looking at a package (eg, https://www.nuget.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/13.0.2) and changing the selected version, I noticed a brief flickering of the screen. What is shown is the image that's in the README tab for this package. I also can tell that the README tab is briefly shown as selected before going back to the Versions tab.



### Repro Steps

1. https://www.nuget.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/13.0.2
2. Select a different version
3. Observe the brief appearance of the README tab's content

### Expected Behavior

Changing versions should not switch tabs.

### Screenshots

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/49205731/9a611cdd-482e-42b2-904f-22a0418a34e9

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Warn when packages include/reference < .NETStandard2.0" (#9984) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: ### Related Problem https://github.com/dotnet/designs/pull/317 ### The Elevator Pitch We should provide a warning when a package author uploads a package targeting an old version of .NETStandard to help push the ecosystem forward based on guidance from a 2020 blog: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/dotnet/the-future-of-net-standard/ **TL;DR** We should use the README, CVE, LICENSE warning infrastructure to detect < .NETStandard2.0 and warn package authors to consider upgrading. Here is some preliminary data to support this(based on https://github.com/dotnet/designs/pull/317#issuecomment-2136010995): For what it is worth, .NETStandard 1.x is < 2%(all versions combined) of assemblies on NuGet.org. .NETStandard 2.0 is ~23% and .NETStandard 2.1 is ~2%. Just a quick query, but hopefully helps in this conversation. In addition, people can use [NuGet.org's newish Search by TFM feature ](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/introducing-search-by-target-framework-on-nuget-org/) to help find specific packages w/ those assets. .NET Standard 1.X: .NET Standard 2.0: .NET Standard 2.1: ### Additional Context and Details _No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Enable package source mapping via msbuild properties" (#13507) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

MSBuild.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

Per https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/msbuild-targets#restore-target I can define restoreSources to provide a list of packageSources.  But when I do so, I get an error at restore time:

error NU1507: There are 2 package sources defined in your configuration. When using central package management, please map your package sources with package source mapping (https://aka.ms/nuget-package-source-mapping) or specify a single package source.

I don't see any method of defining package source mapping as an msbuild property.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Pipeline changes are not clear about which release branch they apply to" (#13367) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
As someone who has recently had to cherry-pick multiple CI Pipeline changes to release branches, I can say it's time consuming and meticulous work to determine which parts of which commits ought to be cherry-picked.

Philosophies vary whether we need to update release branch pipelines frequently, but I would like this to become part of the conscious effort when writing a PR description.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Rebuilding in VS causes unnecessary restores" (#13505) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

VS internal preview

### Worked before?

Before https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/5819

### Impact

Other

### Repro Steps & Context

Firstly, the regression required you use a version of VS with this dotnet/project-system change: https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/pull/9470

Second, it might not have a user observable regression. It's a perf regression only.  If it's observable, then the timestamp on the project.assets.json file in the obj folder will change, even if the contents do not.

But the repro steps are to open a solution with SDK style projects, and then "rebuild" (not just "build) the solution. In NuGet.Commands.dll's RestoreCommand.CommitAsync, it will think the assets file has changed, but it should not have.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Mention existence of Central Package Management on page for NU1604" (#13500) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This is mainly a documentation request - happy to refile if this needs to be reported somewhere different.

I am using `dotnet` 6.0.400 on Linux.

#### Background

I have a small multi-project solution. All of the projects in this solution use [CPM](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/central-package-management) to manage dependency versions. Since the `dotnet` commands and templates do not use that feature by default, I chose (perhaps poorly) to edit the `Directory.Packages.props` manually through VS Code whenever dependency versions need to change.

#### This particular issue

I wrote invalid XML in my `Directory.Packages.props` - specifically, an unclosed tag. This caused subsequent calls to `dotnet restore` to fail. One error message appears for each dependency, in a form like so:

> MyProject.csproj : warning NU1604: Project dependency Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer does not contain an inclusive lower bound. Include a lower bound in the dependency version to ensure consistent restore results.

If `dotnet restore` is called with _detailed_- or _diagnostic_-level verbosity, I note the following in the output:

> Project "/path/to/solution/Directory.Packages.props" was not imported by "/path/to/dotnet/sdk/6.0.400/NuGet.props" at (35,3), due to the file being invalid.

#### My request

Looking at the official docs for NU1604, I noticed no reference to CPM. Please provide some kind of link, and (if it's not too much trouble) suggest that there might be this kind of situation with a malformed file.

---
#### Document Details

⚠ *Do not edit this section. It is required for docs.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.*

* ID: 520cf107-0d2e-f014-1420-a704ab761424
* Version Independent ID: 7f25b7e4-59d1-e79b-469b-950e3281c859
* Content: [NuGet Warning NU1604](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/errors-and-warnings/nu1604)
* Content Source: [docs/reference/errors-and-warnings/NU1604.md](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/blob/main/docs/reference/errors-and-warnings/NU1604.md)
* Product: **nuget**
* GitHub Login: @zhili1208
* Microsoft Alias: **lzhi**

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as April 8th, 2024" (#72) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as April 8th, 2024. If you validate that packages are repository signed by NuGet.org using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages), the [`NuGet.exe verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, or the [`dotnet nuget verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-nuget-verify) command, you will need to take steps by April 8th, 2024 to avoid disruptions when installing packages from NuGet.org that are signed with the new certificate. 

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blogpost on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-april-8th-2024/
